messageBody:
On Fri, Jun 13, 2008 at 11:16 PM, J. B. Rainsberger
<jbrains762@...> wrote:
>>
>> First up I work with Phil and we've had this discussion a few times in
>> the past. For the most part I don't think I would use this feature a
>> whole ton but there is one case that I can of.
>>
>> If I'm invited to come and help with a project which is struggling
>> with their tests (not having done TDD from the start), I can see using
>> the log files as a way of helping me better understand what's going
>> on. Are there tests without assertions? Are there tests with many
>> assertions? etc.
>>
> I would never claim that logging assertions is useless. I will always
> claim that logging assertions does not deserve to be a core feature of
> JUnit. It should be an extension, and if JUnit makes that extension
> hard to write, then it's time to improve JUnit.

We agree that the logging itself doesn't belong in JUnit. But I think
that the current Assertions make logging impossible without resorting
to byte code injection, AOP or similar techniques with which I'm not
familiar.

I think that my previously suggested solution does the minimum required:
A possible solution:
1) Create a logging interface, with methods like TestStart, AssertXXX,
TestFinish, etc.
2) Create a null instance that is used by default.
3) Use an annotation (Java or C# term - I can never keep them
straight) to mark the logger to use.

Without burdening JUnit with knowledge of logging systems et al.

Thoughts? Kent is this approach viable?

Cheers
Mark Levison
